text: Karl Fergus Connor Miller (2 August 1931 - 24 September 2014) was a British literary editor, critic and writer. He was a founding editor of the London Review of Books from 1979 until 1992. Before this, he was an editor of The Listener magazine from 1963 until 1973. He later reviewed works by writers such as J. G. Ballard, Robert Burns, Graham Greene, Ted Hughes and Ian McEwan for The Times Literary Supplement. Miller was born in the small town of Straiton, Loanhead in Midlothian to the south of Edinburgh, the capital of Scotland. He studied in both Edinburgh and at Downing College of the University of Cambridge. He was married to Jane Collet. They had three children: two sons, Daniel and Sam, and a daughter, Georgia. Miller died on 24 September 2014 at his home in North London, aged 83. ==References== ==Other websites== * Karl Miller at Faber and Faber Category:1931 births Category:2014 deaths Category:Alumni of the University of Cambridge Category:British biographers Category:Academics of the University of London Category:British essayists Category:Scottish journalists Category:Literary critics Category:People from Midlothian
